page.title: 13FAUNA & FLORA OF GREETE CONT
page.content: There are several old farmhouses and barns which also house their quota of wildlife. Stonecrops grow on the walls, lichens on the roofs, and yellow necked mice find shelter in the winter. In summer, swallows nest under the eaves, long eared and pipistrelle bats frequent old attics, and barn owls build nests in the old buildings.There are grass snakes in the gardens, adders on the rough ground, and nine varieties of butterfly have been seen,including holly blue, wall brown, orange tip, painted lady, and green veined white.It is to be hoped that this wealth of fauna and flora will be conserved for future generations to enjoy. See page 3. ST. Mary's.
